clause.text_original: Whereas we saw that the hands of the students of the Torah have slackened ... therefore do we ordain that each of the Communities of the whole kingdom of Castile shall be obliged to establish and provide a Voluntary Fund for Talmud Torah in the following manner: For every head of big cattle slaughtered ... five maravedis; for calves and heifers ... two maravedis; for small cattle ... one maravedi; for wine ... three pence per jar retail, two dinars wholesale; for wine sold to Christians ... half a penny; for weddings ... ten maravedis; for circumcisions ... ten maravedis; for deaths ... upper garment or ten maravedis. No collection from the poor.
clause.text_modern: Every community must collect mandatory contributions to support Torah study. Taxes apply to slaughtered animals, wine sales, weddings, circumcisions, and funerals. Poor families are exempt. Funds must remain exclusively for Torah education.

clause.text_original: We ordain that each community shall assemble ten days before the expiration of tax-farm terms ... choose treasurers ... and no one may use the Fund for any other purpose.
clause.text_modern: Each community must annually appoint two treasurers for the Talmud Torah Fund, meet on schedule, and ensure the funds remain untouched except for educational needs under the authority of the Court Rabbi.

clause.text_original: In places where there is no tax on meat and wine ... they shall create their own ordinance. Communities with fewer than ten families must deliver funds to their tax-collecting community, communities with more families must appoint their own treasurer.
clause.text_modern: Even small communities must contribute to the Torah Fund. Those without established taxes must create their own system. Small communities pay through their host communities, larger ones appoint independent treasurers.

clause.text_original: No community or individual may borrow from or use the Fund for private or public needs. Rabbis' salaries may be paid from it only in communities without alternate funding.
clause.text_modern: The Torah Fund is protected. It cannot be borrowed from or redirected. Only in specific cases may a Rabbi's salary come from it.

clause.text_original: Every community of fifteen families shall maintain a proper teacher for primary school children. Fathers pay according to means, the community covers the rest.
clause.text_modern: Communities with at least fifteen families must hire a qualified teacher for young children. Parents contribute what they can and the community ensures a sustainable salary for the teacher.

clause.text_original: Communities with forty families or more must maintain a Rabbi who teaches Halakhot and Aggadot. His salary comes from meat and wine taxes, the Hakdesh, or the Torah Fund.
clause.text_modern: Larger communities must employ a Rabbi as teacher and spiritual guide. His income should ensure independence from wealthy patrons.

clause.text_original: Each Rabbi shall maintain a Talmudic academy where those desirous of learning may study. He shall lecture at customary hour.
clause.text_modern: Every community Rabbi must operate a local academy offering regular study sessions.

clause.text_original: No teacher may instruct more than twenty five children unless he has an assistant, with an assistant he may teach forty. Communities with fifty children must hire two teachers.
clause.text_modern: One teacher may teach up to 25 students or 40 with an assistant. Larger communities must hire additional teachers.

clause.text_original: Any community of ten families must establish a place for public prayer, that is, a synagogue. Fines apply for failing to attend communal prayers without valid reason.
clause.text_modern: Communities must operate a synagogue and maintain regular minyanim. Habitual absence is penalized.

clause.text_original: Violence in synagogues is severely punished, 200 maravedis for striking, 300 for wounding with a weapon, funds go to Torah study and charity.
clause.text_modern: Violence or threats inside sacred spaces incur heavy fines and sanctions.

clause.text_original: Whereas the number of scholars has become small ... they shall choose judges to decide their cases as has been said and the members of the community shall accept them. They shall gather within ten days to elect new judges yearly. Electors must choose only the most worthy. If no agreement is reached, they must deliberate up to eight days,then notify the Rabbi of the Court.
clause.text_modern: Communities must elect qualified judges annually. Elections must be held promptly, with deliberations limited to eight days. If no agreement is reached, the Court Rabbi appoints the judges.

clause.text_original: Judges shall judge disputes according to Talmudic law, may impose fines with approval of the Rabbi and three Best Men. Litigants may appeal to the Rabbi of the Court.
clause.text_modern: Judges exercise legal authority in civil cases and may impose penalties, subject to oversight. All parties retain the right of appeal to the Court Rabbi.

clause.text_original: Judges must not be related to each other, in accordance with Sanhedrin 11:1.
clause.text_modern: Kinship disqualifies individuals from serving together on the bench to ensure impartiality.

clause.text_original: Judges shall fix meeting days three times a week. Litigants are compelled to appear, failure results in escalating fines to the Charity Fund.
clause.text_modern: Courts meet regularly and litigants must comply with summons. Repeated absences lead to significant fines.

clause.text_original: If a judge is party to a case, he must appear before another judge. If no judge is available, the community must appoint one within three days. Judges cannot try cases involving relatives or conflicts of interest.
clause.text_modern: Judges are subject to the same process as others and must recuse themselves from conflicts of interest.

clause.text_original: Judges may not use judicial authority to alter tax lists, though they may adjudicate tax disputes.
clause.text_modern: Courts may hear tax related complaints but cannot directly change tax distribution.

clause.text_original: If a community requests external judges due to internal conflict, the Court Rabbi may appoint a temporary judge. Without majority request, he may not intervene.
clause.text_modern: Communities may request outside judges when necessary. The Court Rabbi intervenes only with majority approval.

clause.text_original: Judges must grant appeals within a reasonable time. Appellants must swear sincerity and guarantee costs.
clause.text_modern: Appeals are permitted with safeguards to prevent abuse. Appellants must prove good faith and cover expenses.

clause.text_original: Litigants may not submit written briefs without permission. Briefs must avoid insults. No one may advise litigants without written court permission.
clause.text_modern: Written arguments require approval and must remain respectful. Unauthorized legal coaching is prohibited.

clause.text_original: Scribes must record testimony against judges within three days. Failure to do so incurs a fine.
clause.text_modern: Communal scribes must process testimonies promptly or face penalties.

clause.text_original: No judge may order physical seizure of any Jew without a written order stating the cause.
clause.text_modern: Arrest warrants must be written, justified, and witnessed.

clause.text_original: Writs must be served within fifty days, otherwise they lose validity.
clause.text_modern: Legal writs expire if not delivered promptly.

clause.text_original: No Jew shall summon another Jew before Gentile judges. Anyone who does so shall be placed under ban and fined ten pounds of silver for the Talmud Torah and Charity funds. The community must protest and support the accused party.
clause.text_modern: Jews may not bring disputes to Christian courts. Doing so results in excommunication and a major fine. Communities must defend any member taken improperly to external courts.

clause.text_original: Anyone who publicly defames another by calling him apostate, mamzer, or similar derogatory terms shall be fined ten pounds of silver. Money goes to Torah study and charity.
clause.text_modern: Severe insults that damage lineage or reputation are heavily penalized. The fines support communal education and welfare.

clause.text_original: If the insult concerns lineage and the accused is actually of legitimate descent, the court shall impose a greater fine as they see fit.
clause.text_modern: If defamatory claims concerning ancestry are proven false, judges may impose greater penalties due to the seriousness of lineage status.

clause.text_original: Anyone who informs on a fellow Jew to Gentile authorities causing monetary loss shall pay full damages. If he cannot pay, he shall be under ban until restitution is made.
clause.text_modern: Informers who cause financial loss must make full restitution and remain under communal ban if they cannot pay.

clause.text_original: If a person informs in matters concerning life or physical harm, the community shall treat him as one who endangers the public and act according to Rabbinic law..
clause.text_modern: Informers who create life threatening situations are treated as dangerous offenders under Jewish law.

clause.text_original: If a Jew is arrested by Gentile authorities due to another Jew’s accusation, the accuser must justify his words in court. Failure to justify leads to punishment as the judges determine.
clause.text_modern: Whoever causes another Jew to be arrested must prove the legitimacy of the accusation or face sanctions.

clause.text_original: No one may use Gentile authorities to force a betrothal or marriage. Such acts are void, and the perpetrator shall be punished.
clause.text_modern: Jewish marriage law cannot be enforced through Christian courts. Attempts to use external authority invalidate the act and bring penalties.

clause.text_original: If a man imposes coercion on a woman through Gentile officials, the judges shall fine him and remove the threat.
clause.text_modern: Coercion of women through outside authorities is forbidden. Courts intervene to remove the threat and punish the aggressor.

clause.text_original: Anyone who intimidates judges or attempts to influence judgment through threats shall be placed under ban and fined.
clause.text_modern: Threats to judicial independence are severely punished to protect fair legal process.

clause.text_original: No one may sell wine to Christians in a manner that causes disgrace to the community. Violators shall be fined.
clause.text_modern: Wine commerce with Christians must avoid damaging communal reputation. Violations incur penalties.

clause.text_original: If wine is sold improperly and results in community harm, judges may impose stronger sanctions based on circumstances.
clause.text_modern: Courts may increase penalties when wine sales create broader risks or dishonor.

clause.text_original: No Jew shall claim exemption from communal taxes unless he possesses a written document issued by the community. Anyone claiming exemption without such proof shall pay double.
clause.text_modern: Tax exemptions must be officially documented. False exemption claims result in double payment.

clause.text_original: Communities may not grant permanent exemptions for families or individuals. Any exemptions granted in the past are revoked unless renewed with the consent of the Court Rabbi.
clause.text_modern: Long term or inherited tax exemptions are invalid unless newly confirmed by the Court Rabbi.

clause.text_original: If a person renders special services to the community, temporary exemptions may be granted for a set period and must be recorded in writing.
clause.text_modern: Temporary exemptions are allowed as compensation for community service but must be time-limited and documented.

clause.text_original: Anyone who feels taxed unfairly may appeal to the judges. Judges must hear his claim within eight days, and may adjust the tax only for clear injustice.
clause.text_modern: Tax disputes must be reviewed promptly. Adjustments occur only when clear inequity is demonstrated.

clause.text_original: If a community is found guilty of tax abuse, they must correct the distribution and compensate the injured party.
clause.text_modern: Communities must rectify unfair tax practices and provide restitution to those harmed.

clause.text_original: Widows and orphans shall not be taxed more than the proportion established by previous communal custom. Judges must protect their rights.
clause.text_modern: Widows and orphans receive special protection against excessive taxation and rely on judicial oversight.

clause.text_original: Communities must maintain equal tax rates on meat and wine for all residents. No butcher or wine seller may privately alter rates. Violators pay fines to the Talmud Torah Fund.
clause.text_modern: Tax rates on meat and wine must be uniform. Secret alterations or favoritism are penalized.

clause.text_original: Anyone who hides income or property to avoid taxation shall be taxed triple the concealed amount.
clause.text_modern: Tax evasion results in a penalty equal to three times the concealed value.

clause.text_original: Community assemblies must be publicly announced. Decisions made without proper notice are void unless confirmed later by the judges.
clause.text_modern: Communal decisions require public notice. Unannounced meetings produce invalid rulings unless later ratified.

clause.text_original: No Jewish woman may wear apparel, jewelry, or ornaments in imitation of Christian noblewomen. Any violation shall result in fines determined by the judges and the Court Rabbi.
clause.text_modern: Women are prohibited from adopting Christian aristocratic clothing or jewelry. Courts impose fines for violations to maintain communal distinction.

clause.text_original: No Jewish man may wear clothing or accessories patterned after Christian knights or nobles. Anyone found doing so shall be fined and compelled to remove the prohibited garment.
clause.text_modern: Jewish men may not imitate the attire of Christian elites, especially martial or noble dress. Offenders face fines and must abandon the practice.

clause.text_original: Each community, with approval of the Court Rabbi, may establish additional rules concerning modesty and dress appropriate to local circumstances. These rules must be publicized.
clause.text_modern: Communities may set stricter or more specific dress regulations based on local needs, with Rabbinic approval and public notice.

clause.text_original: At feasts, weddings, and celebrations, no Jew shall imitate the customs of Gentiles in entertainment, musical troupes, or excessive display. Fines support the Talmud Torah and charity funds.
clause.text_modern: Festive gatherings must avoid Christian style pageantry or extravagant entertainment. Violations lead to fines benefiting communal education and welfare institutions.

term.gloss: study of Torah, Talmud Torah fund
Court Rabbi, head of the rabbinic court
